item.title: "Divorced from Reality": Economist Dean Baker Fact-Checks Trump's Primetime Speech
item.description: President Trump praised the state of the U.S. economy in a primetime address Wednesday evening, even though new government statistics show the nation’s unemployment rate is at a new four-year high of 4.6%. Dean Baker, senior economist at the Center for Economic and Policy Research, says Trump’s aides should be “wondering about the man’s sanity” after Wednesday’s speech. “This is utterly divorced from reality.” Though Trump blames former President Biden for the poor economy, Baker notes that Trump had inherited an “incredibly strong economy by almost every measure imaginable.”
item.source:markdown: President Trump praised the state of the U.S. economy in a primetime address Wednesday evening, even though new government statistics show the nation’s unemployment rate is at a new four-year high of 4.6%. Dean Baker, senior economist at the Center for Economic and Policy Research, says Trump’s aides should be “wondering about the man’s sanity” after Wednesday’s speech. “This is utterly divorced from reality.” Though Trump blames former President Biden for the poor economy, Baker notes that Trump had inherited an “incredibly strong economy by almost every measure imaginable.”

item.title: How Venezuelan crude could shake things up for Canadian producers
item.description: Venezuela's bitumen-heavy oil is virtually identical to Canada's and the South American country has the largest proven reserves in the world. But Venezuelan oil has essentially disappeared from world markets over the past 20 years. U.S. President Donald Trump's threats to invade Venezuela have opened up the prospect that it could one day return, with huge implications for Canada.

![A pair of pumpjacks are bisected by a rainbow.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/72155439-8df1-4fcb-964f-3701acfbc1c7,1766070648146/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C78%2C2000%2C1125%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Venezuela's bitumen-heavy oil is virtually identical to Canada's and the South American country has the largest proven reserves in the world. item.title: UK supreme court upholds appeal in 'Topper' Thompson case

item.title: 47,000 families to benefit from childcare subsidy changes
item.description: The threshold under which families receive subsidies for childcare is to be raised as part of plans for the early learning and school age childcare sector, announced by the Minister for Children.

item.title: Kerry family 'shattered' as man, 84, murdered by friend
item.description: The granddaughter of an 84-year-old man murdered by his long-time friend in Co Kerry last year has said their entire family was shattered, as it happened just three months after the death of her grandmother.
item.source:markdown: The granddaughter of an 84-year-old man murdered by his long-time friend in Co Kerry last year has said their entire family was shattered, as it happened just three months after the death of her grandmother.

item.title: GAA planning 'high performance licence' over team costs
item.description: The Gaelic Athletic Association is aiming to introduce a "high-performance licence" with a view to controlling the amount of money being spent by inter-county teams, president Jarlath Burns has revealed.
item.source:markdown: The Gaelic Athletic Association is aiming to introduce a "high-performance licence" with a view to controlling the amount of money being spent by inter-county teams, president Jarlath Burns has revealed.

item.title: McAleese: 2027 integration realistic despite resistance
item.description: The Steering Group on Integration (SGI) chaired by former president Mary McAleese has said "pockets of resistance" to the merger of the GAA, LGFA and Camogie Association have not hampered their work, with a target date of 2027 remaining a "realisable target".
item.source:markdown: The Steering Group on Integration (SGI) chaired by former president Mary McAleese has said "pockets of resistance" to the merger of the GAA, LGFA and Camogie Association have not hampered their work, with a target date of 2027 remaining a "realisable target".

item.title: NAMA's lifetime contribution to State up €100m to €5.6bn
item.description: The National Asset Management Agency has announced its final surplus transfer of €450m to the State and said its overall lifetime contribution had increased by €100m more than projected, to €5.6 billion.
item.source:markdown: The National Asset Management Agency has announced its final surplus transfer of €450m to the State and said its overall lifetime contribution had increased by €100m more than projected, to €5.6 billion.

item.title: Paddy Power Betfair to pay £2m to UK Gambling Commission
item.description: Paddy Power Betfair has agreed to pay £2m (€2.28m) after the UK gambling watchdog found it failed to step in quickly enough when customers were showing concerning betting behaviours, which saw one gambler stake £86,000 in just over two weeks.

item.title: FIFA slashes price of some World Cup tickets after global fan backlash

item.title: Why is the U.K. rethinking puberty blockers?
item.description: Today, an in-depth look at puberty blockers and their use on minors with gender dysphoria. These drugs have come under an enormous amount of scrutiny in recent years, with some questioning their benefits, safety and long-term impact. After banning the use of puberty blockers for gender treatment of people under 18, a new clinical trial in the U.K. aims to get to the bottom of those concerns. Azeen Ghorayshi is a science and gender reporter for the New York Times. She’ll parse through what we know and don’t know about the effects of blockers in minors, how this became a hugely divisive and politicized debate around the world, and whether this new trial could change our understanding. For transcripts of Front Burner, please visit: https://www.cbc.ca/radio/frontburner/transcripts [https://www.cbc.ca/radio/frontburner/transcripts]
item.source:markdown:
![Abstract image of a burner on a stove](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/b160fe9c-f2a8-490b-a969-72f55ff4bd73,1760988313788/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Today, an in-depth look at puberty blockers and their use on minors with gender dysphoria. These drugs have come under an enormous amount of scrutiny in recent years, with some questioning their benefits, safety and long-term impact. After banning the use of puberty blockers for gender treatment of people under 18, a new clinical trial in the U.K. aims to get to the bottom of those concerns. Azeen Ghorayshi is a science and gender reporter for the New York Times. She’ll parse through what we know and don’t know about the effects of blockers in minors, how this became a hugely divisive and politicized debate around the world, and whether this new trial could change our understanding. For transcripts of Front Burner, please visit: https://www.cbc.ca/radio/frontburner/transcripts \[https://www.cbc.ca/radio/frontburner/transcripts\]

item.description: The Russian anti-Kremlin feminist punk band and art collective known as Pussy Riot was designated an extremist organization by a Moscow court on Monday, banning its activities inside Russia as part of a wider crackdown on dissenting voices.

The Russian anti-Kremlin feminist punk band and art collective known as Pussy Riot was designated an extremist organization by a Moscow court on Monday, banning its activities inside Russia as part of a wider crackdown on dissenting voices.

item.title: Alessandro Gisotti named new President of the EBU Radio News Group
item.description:
The Deputy Editorial Director of Vatican Media, Alessandro Gisotti, succeeds German journalist Stephanie Pieper of Rundfunk Berlin-Brandenburg, as President of the EBU Radio News Group. “I am convinced that radio remains essential in the era of Artificial Intelligence because it offers reliable information and a connection with the community that algorithms cannot replace,” he says.

Read all
item.source:markdown:

[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/vatican-city/news/2025-12/alessandro-gisotti-ebu-radio-news-group-president.html)

item.title: Aid deprioritised as commercial goods flow into Gaza, UN warns
item.description: Humanitarian assistance in Gaza is being delayed because aid cargo is routinely deprioritised in favour of commercial goods, the UN’s aid coordination office (OCHA) warned on Monday, as winter storms continue to worsen already dire living conditions for displaced families.

item.title: Living Ancestors:’ Voices of African Sisters are a testament of resilience
item.description:
Countless stories of courage go untold, but the book “Living Ancestors” emerges as a voice for the unseen, the unheard and the deeply faithful women who have shape Africa’s spiritual and social spaces through decades of consecrated service. This ground-breaking work has been brought to life by Sr. Mumbi Kigutha of the Sister of the Precious blood Dayton, Ohio, CPPS, offers a rare glimpse into their lived experiences.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Countless stories of courage go untold, but the book “Living Ancestors” emerges as a voice for the unseen, the unheard and the deeply faithful women who have shape Africa’s spiritual and social spaces through decades of consecrated service. This ground-breaking work has been brought to life by Sr. Mumbi Kigutha of the Sister of the Precious blood Dayton, Ohio, CPPS, offers a rare glimpse into their lived experiences.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/church/news/2025-12/sisters-project-african-religious-resilience-living-ancestors.html)

item.title: Pope prays for victims of Sydney attack: ‘Enough with antisemitic violence!’
item.description:
Speaking with the groups that donated this year’s Vatican Christmas Tree and Nativity Scene, Pope Leo XIV highlights God’s closeness to humanity and calls for prayers for those who suffer on account of war and violence, especially the victims of Sunday’s terror attack on the Jewish community in Sydney, Australia.

Read all

item.title: Lai convicted of national security charges in Hong Kong
item.description: Hong Kong pro-democracy media tycoon Jimmy Lai has been found guilty on two counts of foreign collusion and of seditious publication, in one of the Chinese city's highest-profile national security trials.
item.source:markdown: Hong Kong pro-democracy media tycoon Jimmy Lai has been found guilty on two counts of foreign collusion and of seditious publication, in one of the Chinese city's highest-profile national security trials.

item.title: Will Gavin campaign review quash potential mutiny in FF?
item.description: Since Jim Gavin stepped down as Fianna Fáil's presidential candidate more than two months ago, there has been speculation about Micheál Martin's future as party leader. Will the review quash rumours or invigorate such mutinous murmurs?
item.source:markdown: Since Jim Gavin stepped down as Fianna Fáil's presidential candidate more than two months ago, there has been speculation about Micheál Martin's future as party leader. Will the review quash rumours or invigorate such mutinous murmurs?

item.title: Man, 20s, injured after shooting in north Dublin
item.description: A man, aged in his 20s, has been injured after sustaining injuries in a shooting in north Dublin, gardaí have said.
item.source:markdown: A man, aged in his 20s, has been injured after sustaining injuries in a shooting in north Dublin, gardaí have said.

item.title: Director Rob Reiner and his wife found dead in Los Angeles home, with homicide unit investigating
item.description: Director-actor Rob Reiner and his wife, Michele, were the two people found dead Sunday at a Los Angeles home owned by Reiner, according to a law enforcement official briefed on the investigation.

item.title: Hamas says Israel killing commander threatens ceasefire
item.description: Israel's assassination of a senior Hamas commander threatens the viability of the Gaza ceasefire, the chief negotiator of the militant group has said, calling on US President Donald Trump to demand Israel comply with the terms of the truce.
item.source:markdown: Israel's assassination of a senior Hamas commander threatens the viability of the Gaza ceasefire, the chief negotiator of the militant group has said, calling on US President Donald Trump to demand Israel comply with the terms of the truce.

item.title: Social media 'geopolitical battleground', says Andrews
item.description: Irish MEP Barry Andrews has warned that social media has "become a geopolitical battleground".
item.source:markdown: Irish MEP Barry Andrews has warned that social media has "become a geopolitical battleground".

item.title: Syria arrests 5 over suspected ties to deadly ambush of U.S., Syrian military convoy
item.description: Two U.S. army soldiers and a civilian interpreter were killed by an attacker who targeted a convoy of American and Syrian forces before being shot dead. The Syrian Interior Ministry has described the attacker as a member of the Syrian security forces suspected of sympathizing with ISIS.
item.source:markdown:
![A soldier mounts a flag atop of vehicle.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/4fdc3684-3a1c-42a3-ba82-6f2f32ed14d5,1765746530276/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C285%2C5472%2C3078%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Two U.S. army soldiers and a civilian interpreter were killed by an attacker who targeted a convoy of American and Syrian forces before being shot dead. The Syrian Interior Ministry has described the attacker as a member of the Syrian security forces suspected of sympathizing with ISIS.

item.title: 14 rescued as trawler runs aground off Daingean Uí Chúis
item.description: A large trawler was driven onto rocks outside Cuan an Daingin. The trawler had been driven aground on rocks near Binn Bán beach, where weather conditions were extremely poor with rough sea conditions.
item.source:markdown: A large trawler was driven onto rocks outside Cuan an Daingin. The trawler had been driven aground on rocks near Binn Bán beach, where weather conditions were extremely poor with rough sea conditions.

item.title: Funeral told Mary Holt showed up for 'those most in need'
item.description: Mary Holt, who was killed in an arson attack in Edenderry along with her grand-nephew Tadgh Farrell last week, has been remembered at her funeral mass as someone who "showed up for others when they were most in need".
item.source:markdown: Mary Holt, who was killed in an arson attack in Edenderry along with her grand-nephew Tadgh Farrell last week, has been remembered at her funeral mass as someone who "showed up for others when they were most in need".

item.title: Zelenskyy offers to drop NATO aspirations, remains against ceding territory to Russia
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy on Sunday voiced readiness to drop his country's bid to join NATO in exchange for Western security guarantees, but rejected the U.S. push for ceding territory to Russia as he held talks with U.S. envoys on ending the war.

item.title: Watch: 'Hero' tackles and disarms gunman at Bondi Beach
item.description: New South Wales Premier Chris Minns has hailed as a hero a man who tackled and disarmed one of the gunmen during the Bondi Beach attack today.
item.source:markdown: New South Wales Premier Chris Minns has hailed as a hero a man who tackled and disarmed one of the gunmen during the Bondi Beach attack today.

item.title: Silver for Irish men's team in Euro Cross Country event
item.description: Ireland have won a silver medal in the men's team event at the European Cross Country Championships in Portugal, the first time they have finished on the podium in 25 years.
item.source:markdown: Ireland have won a silver medal in the men's team event at the European Cross Country Championships in Portugal, the first time they have finished on the podium in 25 years.

item.title: More garda patrols at Jewish centres, events after attack
item.description: Gardaí have said there will be increased garda patrols at centres and events for the Irish Jewish community following the terrorist attack targeting the Jewish community in Sydney this morning.
item.source:markdown: Gardaí have said there will be increased garda patrols at centres and events for the Irish Jewish community following the terrorist attack targeting the Jewish community in Sydney this morning.

item.title: Zelensky willing to drop NATO goal for security guarantee
item.description: Ukraine has relinquished its ambition of joining the NATO military alliance in exchange for Western security guarantees as a compromise to end the war with Russia, President Volodymyr Zelensky said ahead of talks with US envoys in Berlin.
item.source:markdown: Ukraine has relinquished its ambition of joining the NATO military alliance in exchange for Western security guarantees as a compromise to end the war with Russia, President Volodymyr Zelensky said ahead of talks with US envoys in Berlin.

item.title: Ukraine drops NATO goal as peace talks in Berlin extended
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky offered to drop Ukraine's aspirations to join the NATO military alliance as he held hours of talks with US envoys in Berlin to end the war with Russia, with negotiations set to continue tomorrow.
item.source:markdown: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky offered to drop Ukraine's aspirations to join the NATO military alliance as he held hours of talks with US envoys in Berlin to end the war with Russia, with negotiations set to continue tomorrow.

item.title: Pope: Jesus' words 'free us from the prison of despair'
item.description:
After celebrating Mass for the Jubilee of Prisoners, Pope Leo delivers his Angelus address for the third Sunday of Advent, saying that Christian joy endures "when life seems to lose its meaning and everything appears darker.”

item.title: UN marks first World Turkic Language Family Day
item.description: The UN cultural agency, UNESCO, is preparing to celebrate the first ever World Turkic Language Family Day on Monday, following a decision by UNESCO’s General Conference in Samarkand to establish 15 December as an annual observance.
item.source:markdown: The UN cultural agency, UNESCO, is preparing to celebrate the first ever World Turkic Language Family Day on Monday, following a decision by UNESCO’s General Conference in Samarkand to establish 15 December as an annual observance.

item.title: From farm to classroom: Feeding children and supporting farmers in Timor-Leste
item.description: It’s a win-win recipe: schoolchildren eat a free, nutritious meal every day and local farmers gain reliable access to local markets.
item.source:markdown: It’s a win-win recipe: schoolchildren eat a free, nutritious meal every day and local farmers gain reliable access to local markets.

item.title: Guterres condemns deadly attack on Hannukah celebration in Sydney
item.description: UN Secretary-General António Guterres has strongly condemned the “heinous deadly attack” on Sunday against Jewish families gathered in Sydney, Australia, to celebrate Hanukkah.
item.source:markdown: UN Secretary-General António Guterres has strongly condemned the “heinous deadly attack” on Sunday against Jewish families gathered in Sydney, Australia, to celebrate Hanukkah.

item.title: Dialogue is ‘not naïve – it’s necessary’ as global divisions deepen, UN Riyadh forum hears
item.description: The 11th Global Forum of the UN Alliance of Civilizations opened in Riyadh on Sunday with a blunt message for a world riven by distrust: dialogue is not a luxury – it’s a survival strategy.
item.source:markdown: The 11th Global Forum of the UN Alliance of Civilizations opened in Riyadh on Sunday with a blunt message for a world riven by distrust: dialogue is not a luxury – it’s a survival strategy.

item.title: ‘Almost invisible crisis’: UN urges world not to look away from Myanmar
item.description: Despite widespread suffering driven by conflict, displacement and disasters, Myanmar’s humanitarian emergency has become “almost invisible” to the world, the UN’s senior official in the country has warned.
item.source:markdown: Despite widespread suffering driven by conflict, displacement and disasters, Myanmar’s humanitarian emergency has become “almost invisible” to the world, the UN’s senior official in the country has warned.

item.title: Pope Leo calls for end to violence in Democratic Republic of Congo
item.description:
During the Sunday Angelus Pope Leo appeals for those fighting in the Democratic Republic of Congo to stop the violence which has broken out and return to constructive dialogue. He also remembers the newly beatified martyrs in two separate beatifications in Spain and in France on Saturday 13 December.

Read all

item.title: Pope Leo: Flowers can bloom even in prisons
item.description:
During his homily on the Sunday of the Jubilee of Prisoners, Pope Leo XIV challenges both inmates and those responsible for the prisons to hold on to hope and he reminds everyone “that no human being is defined only by his or her actions and that justice is always a process of reparation and reconciliation.”

Read all
item.source:markdown:
During his homily on the Sunday of the Jubilee of Prisoners, Pope Leo XIV challenges both inmates and those responsible for the prisons to hold on to hope and he reminds everyone “that no human being is defined only by his or her actions and that justice is always a process of reparation and reconciliation.”
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-12/pope-with-mercy-forgiveness-flowers-can-bloom-even-in-prisons.html)

item.title: Suspected Bondi gunmen were father and son, police say

item.title: Ukraine war sparks European march towards conscription
item.description: A number of European countries have reintroduced conscription or a form of incentivised military service for their young citizens since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022. But what systems exist across the continent?

item.title: Challenging period ahead as flu season gathers pace
item.description: Ireland has experienced bad influenza seasons before, and the weeks ahead are shaping up to offer a testing season of festive flu and colds. The flu this winter has come a few weeks early and is mainly being driven by a mutated A(H3N2) virus. Seasons that start early, tend to be more severe.
item.source:markdown: Ireland has experienced bad influenza seasons before, and the weeks ahead are shaping up to offer a testing season of festive flu and colds. The flu this winter has come a few weeks early and is mainly being driven by a mutated A(H3N2) virus. Seasons that start early, tend to be more severe.

item.title: Eleanor the Great star June Squibb: an A-lister at 96
item.description: Nonagenarian June Squibb delivers one of the year's best performances - and Scarlett Johansson makes her feature directorial debut - in Eleanor the Great, a comedy-drama about a misunderstanding that becomes a lie and gets very, very out of hand.

item.title: A year of 'dramatic highs and lows': 2025's 'roller-coaster ride' for the Royals
item.description: In the annals of Royal Family history, 2025 will be remembered as the year the monarch took the virtually unprecedented step of stripping his younger brother of his titles and honours. But as much as the scandal surrounding the former prince now known only as Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor garnered headlines, there were other notable moments this year that sent signals about the monarchy and its future.
item.source:markdown:
![A person standing talks to a person seated in an elaborate chair, with a Canadian flag between them.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/10bf0528-3921-4d36-aba0-6c22dc685fbc,1765568073318/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C7856%2C4419%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
In the annals of Royal Family history, 2025 will be remembered as the year the monarch took the virtually unprecedented step of stripping his younger brother of his titles and honours. But as much as the scandal surrounding the former prince now known only as Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor garnered headlines, there were other notable moments this year that sent signals about the monarchy and its future.
